byline.contributor: Ahmad Shakib and Jawad Sukhanyar contributed reporting.

abstract: Mob killing in Afghanistan of woman Farkhunda, 27-year-old student of Islam who was falsely accused of burning Quran in Muslim shrine, sparked national outrage, but most of accused, some of whom never stood trial, received minor punishments; her murder and legal system's response call into question over decade of Western attempts in Afghanistan to impose rule of law and improve status of women (Series: Women's War).
lead_paragraph: At first, the trial and convictions in the death of Farkhunda Malikzada seemed a victory in the long struggle to give Afghan women their due in court. But a deeper look suggests otherwise.

headline.main: Flawed Justice After a Mob Killed an Afghan Woman
headline.print_headline: A Mob Killing and Flawed Justice

snippet: At first, the trial and convictions in the death of Farkhunda Malikzada seemed a victory in the long struggle to give Afghan women their due in court. But a deeper look suggests otherwise.
